aluminum.intro: Aluminium is the world's most produced non-ferrous metal, refined from bauxite ore through the Bayer process (producing alumina) and then the Hall-Héroult electrolytic smelting process. Bauxite is a red-brown laterite ore found in tropical and subtropical regions. Aluminium production is extremely energy-intensive — smelters locate near cheap hydroelectric or coal power. China produces over 55% of global aluminium. The LME aluminium contract is the global benchmark.
aluminum.materials: Red-brown bauxite ore with pisolitic texture, white alumina powder, molten silvery metal in electrolytic pot, solid silvery ingot with slight blue-white sheen, thin rolled aluminium sheet, extruded profile cross-section, recycled crushed cans.

cobalt.intro: Cobalt is a hard silvery-blue metal critical for lithium-ion battery cathodes (used in electric vehicles and electronics), superalloys for jet engines, and industrial catalysts. Over 70% of global cobalt is mined in the Democratic Republic of Congo, often as a byproduct of copper mining. Cobalt's supply concentration and role in the energy transition make it one of the most geopolitically sensitive metals. Refined cobalt is traded as metal cathodes, broken cathode pieces, or cobalt hydroxide intermediate.
cobalt.materials: Silvery-blue metallic surface with slight lustre, dark grey-black cobalt-bearing ore with copper green staining, blue cobalt oxide powder, shiny cathode plate, bright blue pigment, lithium-ion battery cell cross-section showing cathode layer.

copper.intro: Copper is the world's most important industrial conductor metal — essential for electrical wiring, motors, electronics, plumbing, and increasingly for EV motors and renewable energy systems. Mined primarily from porphyry copper deposits in massive open pits. Chile produces roughly 25% of global supply. The LME copper contract (Grade A cathode, 99.99% purity) is the global benchmark. Copper's conductivity, malleability, and corrosion resistance make it irreplaceable in modern infrastructure.

gallium.intro: Gallium is a soft silvery metal with the unusual property of melting just above room temperature (29.76°C) — it will melt in your hand. Critical for semiconductors (gallium arsenide and gallium nitride for LEDs, 5G communications, and military radar), gallium is almost entirely produced as a byproduct of aluminium refining from bauxite. China produces over 95% of global primary gallium, making it a strategically sensitive material subject to export controls.

germanium.intro: Germanium is a metalloid (between metal and non-metal) critical for fibre-optic telecommunications, infrared optics (night-vision and thermal imaging), and solar cell substrates. Like gallium, it is produced primarily as a byproduct — from zinc refining residues and coal fly ash. China produces over 60% of global germanium and has imposed export controls. Germanium is transparent to infrared radiation, making it essential for military and civilian thermal imaging lenses.

hrc_steel.intro: Hot-rolled coil (HRC) is the most widely traded form of flat steel, produced by passing heated steel slabs through a series of rolling stands to reduce thickness to 1.5-12mm. The coil is the starting material for automotive panels, structural sections, pipe, appliances, and general manufacturing. HRC is benchmarked regionally — CRU Midwest (US), NW Europe, and China — with prices varying by market. China produces over 50% of global crude steel.

indium.intro: Indium is a soft silvery-white metal so soft you can scratch it with a fingernail. Its primary use is in indium tin oxide (ITO), a transparent electrical conductor sputtered onto glass for LCD and OLED display screens, touchscreens, and solar cells. Indium is produced almost entirely as a byproduct of zinc refining. China produces roughly 50% of global indium, followed by South Korea and Japan. Annual global production is only about 900 tonnes, making it a minor but irreplaceable high-tech metal.

iron_ore.intro: Iron ore is the raw material for steelmaking — the world's most produced and consumed metal. Hematite (Fe₂O₃, red-brown) and magnetite (Fe₃O₄, black magnetic) are the primary ore minerals. Australia and Brazil together supply roughly 60% of global seaborne iron ore, with the Pilbara (Australia) and Carajás (Brazil) as the world's premier mining regions. The 62% Fe CFR China benchmark (Platts IODEX) is the global price reference. Iron ore is shipped as fines, lump, or pellets.

iron_ore_cny.intro: Iron ore traded in Chinese yuan (CNY) on the Dalian Commodity Exchange (DCE) is the world's most liquid iron ore futures contract by volume. China imports over 70% of global seaborne iron ore — approximately 1.2 billion tonnes annually — primarily from Australia and Brazil. The DCE contract represents 100 tonnes of 62% Fe fines delivered to Chinese ports. Chinese port stockpiles of iron ore at any given time represent a significant inventory buffer and price signal.

lead.intro: Lead is a dense, soft, bluish-grey metal historically used for plumbing, paint, and ammunition, now primarily used in lead-acid batteries (over 85% of demand) for vehicles, backup power, and industrial applications. Lead is mined from galena (lead sulphide, PbS) — a heavy, shiny dark grey cubic mineral. Major producers include China, Australia, and the US. The LME lead contract is the global benchmark. Lead is one of the most recycled metals — over 60% of supply comes from secondary (recycled) lead.

lithium.intro: Lithium is the lightest metal, critical for rechargeable lithium-ion batteries powering electric vehicles, electronics, and grid-scale energy storage. Produced from two sources: hard-rock spodumene mining (Australia dominates) and brine evaporation (South America's Lithium Triangle — Chile, Argentina, Bolivia). The energy transition has driven explosive demand growth. Lithium is traded as lithium carbonate (Li₂CO₃) or lithium hydroxide (LiOH), with China converting most raw material into battery-grade chemicals.

magnesium.intro: Magnesium is the lightest structural metal, 33% lighter than aluminium and 75% lighter than steel, making it essential for lightweight automotive components, aerospace parts, and electronic device housings. Produced by two routes: the Pidgeon process (thermally reducing magnesium oxide with ferrosilicon in retorts — dominant in China) and electrolytic reduction of magnesium chloride from seawater or brine. China produces over 85% of global magnesium using the coal-intensive Pidgeon process.

manganese.intro: Manganese is essential for steelmaking — over 90% of production goes into steel as a deoxidiser and alloying element. Without manganese, steel would be too brittle to use. The metal is also increasingly important in lithium-ion battery cathodes (manganese-rich NMC chemistries). Mined as manganese dioxide (MnO₂) or other oxide minerals, typically black-to-grey ores. South Africa holds 75% of global reserves in the Kalahari manganese field. Major producers include South Africa, Gabon, Australia, and China.

molybdenum.intro: Molybdenum is a refractory metal (extremely high melting point — 2,623°C, second only to tungsten) used primarily as an alloying element in high-strength steel and stainless steel for pipelines, automotive components, and chemical processing equipment. It is also used in catalysts for petroleum refining. Most molybdenum is mined as a byproduct of copper mining from porphyry deposits. The US, Chile, China, and Peru are the largest producers. Ferromolybdenum is the standard trade form for steelmaking.

neodymium.intro: Neodymium is a rare earth element essential for the world's strongest permanent magnets (NdFeB — neodymium-iron-boron). These magnets are critical for EV drive motors, wind turbine generators, hard drives, headphones, and guided munitions. Despite being called 'rare earth', neodymium is as abundant as copper — the 'rare' refers to the difficulty of separating it from other rare earths. China dominates mining, separation, and magnet manufacturing, controlling over 85% of global supply. Inner Mongolia's Bayan Obo is the world's largest rare earth mine.

nickel.intro: Nickel is a silvery-white metal essential for stainless steel (accounting for ~70% of demand) and increasingly for lithium-ion battery cathodes in EVs. Mined from two ore types: sulphide deposits (higher grade, underground, in Canada and Russia) and laterite deposits (lower grade, open-pit, in Indonesia and the Philippines). Indonesia has become the world's largest producer through massive laterite processing investment. The LME nickel contract is the global benchmark, though Indonesian NPI (nickel pig iron) has disrupted traditional pricing.

soda_ash.intro: Soda ash (sodium carbonate, Na₂CO₃) is a fundamental industrial chemical used in glass manufacturing (50% of demand), detergents, chemicals, and increasingly in lithium carbonate production for EV batteries. Produced by two routes: mining of natural trona ore (dominant in the US — Wyoming has the world's largest trona deposits) and the synthetic Solvay process (dominant in China, EU, and India). The US Green River Basin in Wyoming supplies roughly 90% of US production and is the world's largest natural source.

steel.intro: Steel rebar (reinforcing bar) is the most consumed form of long steel product, embedded in concrete to provide tensile strength in construction. Produced primarily in electric arc furnaces (EAFs) melting scrap steel, or from integrated blast-furnace-BOF routes. Rebar is the backbone of global construction — every building, bridge, and road contains tonnes of it. China produces over 50% of global steel and consumes most of its own rebar domestically. The Shanghai Futures Exchange rebar contract is the world's most liquid steel derivative.

tellurium.intro: Tellurium is one of the rarest stable elements in Earth's crust — rarer than gold — yet essential for cadmium telluride (CdTe) thin-film solar panels, the fastest-growing and lowest-cost solar technology. Almost all tellurium is recovered as a byproduct of copper refining, from the anode slimes that collect during electrolytic copper refining. Global production is only about 500 tonnes per year. Major sources include China, Japan, and Russia. First Solar is the dominant CdTe solar panel manufacturer.

tin.intro: Tin is a soft silvery-white metal primarily used for solder in electronics (48% of demand), tinplate food cans, chemicals, and lead-free solder alloys. Mined from cassiterite (tin oxide, SnO₂) — a heavy dark brown mineral found in alluvial (placer) deposits and hard-rock veins. China and Indonesia are the largest producers, with significant output from Myanmar, Peru, and Bolivia. The LME tin contract is the global benchmark. Tin is the smallest of the LME base metals by production volume.

titanium.intro: Titanium is a strong, lightweight, corrosion-resistant metal used primarily as titanium dioxide pigment (TiO₂ — the world's most important white pigment for paint, plastics, and paper, consuming 95% of titanium ore) and as titanium metal for aerospace, medical implants, and chemical processing. Mined from mineral sands containing ilmenite (FeTiO₃) and rutile (TiO₂). Major producers include Australia, South Africa, Canada, and China. Despite being the ninth most abundant element, titanium metal is expensive due to the complex Kroll reduction process.

uranium.intro: Uranium is the fuel for nuclear power, providing roughly 10% of global electricity. Natural uranium is mined, converted to uranium hexafluoride (UF₆), enriched to increase the proportion of fissile U-235 from 0.7% to 3-5%, then fabricated into fuel pellets and assemblies. Kazakhstan is the world's largest producer using in-situ leach (ISL) mining. Canada's Athabasca Basin contains the world's highest-grade deposits. The spot uranium price is quoted per pound of U₃O₈ (yellowcake).

zinc.intro: Zinc is the fourth most consumed metal globally, primarily used for galvanising steel (providing corrosion protection, ~60% of demand), die-casting alloys, brass, and zinc oxide. Mined from sphalerite (zinc sulphide, ZnS) typically alongside lead. Major producers include China, Peru, and Australia. The LME zinc contract is the global benchmark. Zinc's role in galvanising makes it essential for construction and automotive industries — every galvanised steel product relies on zinc.

gold.intro: Gold is the world's premier monetary metal, store of value, and safe-haven asset. Traded 24 hours a day globally, with LBMA London AM and PM fixes as the benchmark. Gold is extraordinarily dense (19.3 g/cm³), malleable (one ounce can be beaten into 30 square metres of leaf), and chemically inert. Mined from epithermal veins, porphyry deposits, and placer (alluvial) deposits. China, Australia, Russia, and Canada are the largest producers. Central banks hold over 36,000 tonnes in reserves.

palladium.intro: Palladium is a platinum group metal (PGM) primarily used in gasoline engine catalytic converters (80% of demand), where it converts harmful carbon monoxide, hydrocarbons, and nitrogen oxides into CO₂, water, and nitrogen. Russia (Nornickel) and South Africa produce over 75% of global palladium. The metal is silvery-white, lighter than platinum, and has become more expensive than gold in recent years due to tightening emission standards. LPPM and NYMEX are the price benchmarks.

platinum.intro: Platinum is a dense, silvery-white precious metal prized for its catalytic properties, corrosion resistance, and beauty. Primary uses include diesel engine catalytic converters, jewellery, chemical catalysts, and investment. South Africa's Bushveld Complex contains over 70% of global reserves. Platinum is denser than gold (21.45 vs 19.3 g/cm³) and historically traded at a premium to gold, though this relationship has inverted in recent years. The LPPM platinum fix is the global benchmark.

rhodium.intro: Rhodium is the rarest and most expensive of the commonly traded precious metals, a platinum group element with extraordinary catalytic properties and corrosion resistance. Over 80% of rhodium goes into three-way catalytic converters for gasoline engines, where it uniquely catalyses the reduction of nitrogen oxides (NOx). South Africa produces roughly 80% of global supply. Rhodium prices are extremely volatile — ranging from $1,000/oz to over $29,000/oz in recent cycles. Annual global production is only about 30 tonnes.

silver.intro: Silver is both a precious metal (investment, jewellery) and an industrial metal (electronics, solar panels, photography). This dual nature makes silver prices responsive to both financial sentiment and industrial demand. Over 50% of silver demand is now industrial — particularly for silver paste in photovoltaic solar cells, where it provides the electrical contacts. Silver is the best electrical and thermal conductor of any element. Major producers include Mexico, Peru, China, and Poland. The LBMA silver fix is the global benchmark.
